Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Putative nitrate transporter regulates symbiotic nodule development
Award.AbstractNarration: When nitrogen is limited in soils most legume plants form nitrogen-fixing nodules on their roots in symbiosis with soil bacteria called rhizobia. Nodulated legumes utilize bioavailable nitrogen produced within the nodule, reducing nitrogen fertilizer requirements, thereby lowering energy costs and environmental pollution associated with crop production. Recently a gene called NIP was found to be essential for the development of symbiotic nodules in the model legume plant Medicago truncatula. This project seeks to determine the role of NIP in nodule formation and root differentiation. Experiments will discern NIP's developmental and temporal patterns of gene expression in nodules and roots and test how NIP expression at artificially high levels affects nodulation. Cellular approaches will determine where the NIP gene and encoded protein are expressed. The biochemical function of the NIP protein, a predicted transporter, will be assessed in a foreign host as well as directly in wild-type plants and those with a genetic defect in the NIP gene. Physiological experiments will discern whether the NIP transporter is acting as part of a sensor system. The results from these experiments will yield information on the biochemical function of the NIP protein and provide a context for understanding NIP function in nodulation and other plant development pathways. The broader impacts of this project include adding to the knowledge base of nodule development, part of what makes legume plants valuable in agriculture as a source of high-protein, high-fiber food for humans and animals. Training opportunities for a post-doctoral fellow, graduate and undergraduate students in the areas of molecular and cell biology, genetics and biochemistry will be provided by this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All plants require nitrogen for healthy growth, and the majority of commercially-produced plant gain nitrogen from fertilizers supplemented to the soil.  However, legume plants such as soybean, peanut, alfalfa are capable of vigorous growth even when soil nitrogen levels are insufficient to support plant growth. In addition to gaining nitrogen from the soil, these plants can acquire nitrogen through the interaction of their roots with specialized soil bacteria called rhizobia. When associated with the plant, rhizobia utilize energy derived from plant photosynthesis to convert inert nitrogen into a nitrogen source for the plant. This interaction reduces the reliance of crop production on industrially-produced fertilizers. 

The establishment of the plant-rhizobia interaction is complex, requiring correct patterns and timing of plant and bacterial gene expression. We discovered and studied a plant-encoded nitrate transport protein essential for the formation of this beneficial interaction. Through our research, we demonstrated that the protein also transports the plant hormone auxin, providing a link between the regulation of plant-microbe interactions and hormone signaling. This protein is localized at the interface between the plant and microbe, providing further evidence for its regulation of the interaction.  The data show that this protein influences carbon portioning in the plant, a factor that has a major impact on plant growth and productivity.

During this work, we also provided professional scientific training and hands-learning opportunities for college-level science majors and post-graduate scientists.  We also aimed to apply knowledge of this beneficial plant-microbe interaction to identify bacterial strains to enhance crop productivity of modern crops. Specifically, we aimed to isolate and characterize the benefits of rhizobia to interact with the cash-crop lima beans. We isolated 50+ strains of bacteria from legume roots and conducted greenhouse, field and lab studies to measure their impact on plant productivity. After one greenhouse study and three subsequent field studies, we have identified four bacterial strains that potentially could be developed into an agricultural bioinoculant to reduce the financial cost and carbon footprint of lima bean production.
